description: From Middle English rehersen, from Anglo-Norman reherser (“to repeat word-for-word”).

verbs.description: rehearse (third-person singular simple present rehearses, present participle rehearsing, simple past and past participle rehearsed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To repeat, as what has been already said; to tell over again; to recite.
examples: There’s no need to rehearse the same old argument; we’ve heard it before, and we all agree.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To narrate; to relate; to tell.
examples: The witness rehearsed the events of the night before for the listening detectives.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To practise by recitation or repetition in private for experiment and improvement, prior to a public representation, especially in theater
examples: In sober mornings, do not thou reherse
The holy incantation of a verse ...

entries.meaning: (transitive, theater) To cause to rehearse; to instruct by rehearsal.
examples: The director rehearsed the cast incessantly in the days leading up to opening night, and as a result they were tired and cranky when it arrived.

entries.meaning: To contrive and carefully prepare (a story, etc.) to offer consistency.
examples: The Crown argued that the accused had rehearsed her story.
